title: Senate bucks Tuberville's blockade to begin approving military promotions
description: Senate Democrats began holding votes on military promotions after a months-long blockade by Alabama Republican Sen. Tommy Tuberville.

title: There have been attempts to censor more than 1,900 library book titles so far in 2023
description: Most of the scrutinized books were written by or contained subject matter about people of color or members of the LGBTQ+ community, according to research by the American Library Association.

title: A 96-year-old federal judge was barred from hearing cases in a fight over her fitness
description: The unusually public and bitter fight over whether a judge should continue to serve on the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit has sparked a lawsuit and turned judges against one another.

title: A sculptor and a ceramicist who grapple with race win 2023 Heinz Awards for the Arts
description: Kevin Beasley and Roberto Lugo are this year's winners of the the Heinz Awards for the Arts, a prestigious prize that comes with a $250,000 cash award.

title: Philly's 'pastor of the hood' Carl Day weighs in on the 2024 election
description: Carl Day joined NPR to weigh in on the Biden campaign in 2020. We caught up with him to hear what he's thinking heading into 2024.

title: Maryland apologizes to man wrongly convicted of murder and agrees to pay him $340,000
description: Demetrius Smith will be compensated by the state of Maryland after spending years behind bars, including over a year after he had been proven innocent. He was released from prison in 2013.

title: UAW strike latest: GM sends 2,000 workers home in Kansas
description: General Motors had previously warned it would need to stop production at its Fairfax, Kansas, assembly plant, because it relied on parts that came from a Missouri plant that is currently on strike.

title: This Republican senator wants an expanded child tax credit — with work requirements
description: Florida Senator Marco Rubio says the U.S. has lost focus over the last 20 to 30 years and economic policies need to be geared towards creating stable work for families.

title: Azerbaijan and ethnic Armenian separatists agree to halt fighting in disputed enclave
description: Separatist leaders in Nagorno-Karabakh said that after "a lack of concrete actions" by international parties, their forces had few options to ensure civilians' safety.

title: 'Wellness' is a perfect novel for our age, its profound sadness tempered with humor
description: Nathan Hill's stunning new novel about the stories we tell about our lives and our loves, and how we sustain relationships throughout time, is both funny and heartbreaking, sometimes on the same page.

title: The Federal Reserve holds interest rates steady but hints at more action this year
description: The Federal Reserve left interest rates unchanged Wednesday, despite stubborn inflation, although it left the door open to an additional rate hike in November or December.

title: Having a hard time finding Clorox wipes? Blame it on a cyberattack
description: The Clorox Co. — which also includes brands such as Pine-Sol, Brita, Glad and Burt's Bees — says it's operating at a "lower rate of processing" after an August hack on its IT infrastructure.

title: What to know about the tensions between Canada and India over the killing of a Sikh
description: Canada says India is linked to the June killing of Hardeep Singh Nijjar, a prominent activist for the creation of a Sikh homeland in India. India considered Nijjar a terrorist but denies involvement.

title: As the U.S. mulls more aid to Ukraine, Zelenskyy says 'we have the same values'
description: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy is in New York for the U.N. General Assembly. He spoke with NPR's Steve Inskeep about why U.S. aid to Ukraine remains so important.

title: Simone Biles will go to a U.S. record 6th World Championships after 'nail-biting' win
description: Simone Biles, 26, is now the only U.S. woman ever chosen for six World Championships. The star gymnast is heading back to Antwerp, where she competed in her first Worlds in 2013.

title: How wildfire smoke is erasing years of progress toward cleaning up America's air
description: A new study finds that smoke from massive wildfires has eroded about a quarter of the air quality gains from the last few decades.

title: Dear U.N.: Could you add these 4 overlooked items to the General Assembly agenda?
description: A physician from Nigeria and a scientist from Kenya propose ideas for the United Nations to consider — issues important in Africa and other regions that are often neglected by global bodies.

title: Hunter Biden plans to plead not guilty in felony gun case
description: The president's son was indicted last week after a plea deal with federal prosecutors fell apart.

title: Biden is unveiling the American Climate Corps, a program with echoes of the New Deal
description: The White House says the program will provide paid training to 20,000 Americans in its first year. It's much smaller than its New Deal predecessor, but targets a more diverse group of young people.

title: Up First Briefing: Garland testifies; interest rate update; depression-fighting habits
description: Attorney General Merrick Garland will appear before the House Judiciary Committee. The Federal Reserve is expected to hold interest rates steady. These seven habits help reduce depression.

title: Jumping for joy and sisterhood, the 40+ Double Dutch Club holds a playdate for Women
description: Hundreds of women, aged 40 and older, gathered in Chicago recently to jump rope and play other games from their youth. It was the 3rd national playdate held by the Double Dutch Club.

title: A federal agency wants to give safety tips to young adults. So it's dropping an album
description: The Consumer Product Safety Commission's album addresses the most common hazards among those 13-24, through a variety of genres. It's called We're Safety Now Haven't We, and you'll want to hear it.

title: In Morocco's Atlas Mountains, survivors of the quake take stock of all they've lost
description: Survivors of the Sept. 8 earthquake return to devastated villages. "This was our paradise," says a 74-year-old woman. "Everyone in this village is like family to me, and our family is now shattered."

title: At new mental health courts in California, judges will be able to mandate treatment
description: In several California counties, new mental health courts open up in October. Officials hope to persuade people with psychosis to accept treatment. Critics say, it looks more like coercion.

title: GOP presidential hopeful Doug Burgum says he'd leave abortion laws up to the states
description: In a The NPR Politics Podcast interview, the North Dakota governor shares his views on wide-ranging issues, including the role of the federal government in regulating abortion and transgender issues.

title: AG Garland in the hot seat as House Judiciary to probe him on Hunter Biden, Trump
description: Republicans are expected to interrogate him over the investigations into Hunter Biden and former President Donald Trump.

title: Tired of the Republican primary, GOP frontrunner Donald Trump shifts focus to Biden
description: Former President Donald Trump is escalating his attacks on President Biden in another sign his campaign is looking past the Republican primaries — and focusing more on the general election ahead.

title: Fed-up consumers are increasingly going after food companies for misleading claims
description: This week a federal judge in Manhattan allowed a case to move forward against Starbucks over claims its fruit-based drinks were lacking fruit.

title: A NASA astronaut approaches a year in space, the longest time for any American
description: Frank Rubio's first mission broke the record for longest U.S. spaceflight last week. The medical doctor is a lieutenant colonel in the U.S. Army and served as a Blackhawk helicopter pilot.

title: Why the UAW is fighting so hard for these 4 key demands in the auto strike
description: Driving the UAW's tough stance in negotiations with the Big Three automakers is the sense that the union is owed a long-overdue redressal for all the concessions workers made in 2007.
